item.title: Canine Photography Session
item.description:
Today morning I went to a canine photography session organised by safra content creators club. It was held in an open area. First such place I've seen. It's an open area near Alexandra Park. ~20 min walk from nearest bus stop though.

Unfortunately during the shoot, light was too harsh. Sun was high and no clouds in the sky. That made the colors dull in photos.

But today I got convinced dogs can actually smile !!

item.title: Southern Ridges Walk
item.description:
Today (Sunday), I joined my friend's weekend hiking group to go for a walk in Southern Ridges. I remember doing this route sometime back, but couldn't find any record.

We started around 8am. Got caught in a light rain somewhere in the middle, for about 20 min.

The scenery was green with occasional glimpses of buildings. The weather was humid (today it's more humid than Singapore usual), and we were drenched with sweat.

We walked for about 10 km, and finished the walk around 11am. The lunch was at a food court in Buona-Vista. In the food court, there's a famous chicken rice stall with a long queue. Queue was too long for me, so I had some fried chicken rice from another stall, and took a bus home.

item.title: Waacking Portraits
item.description:
Capturing a dance in a single frame is impossible. But it should be possible to capture at least a part of the dance, may be a movement and the dancer's emotion? Following are the results of my attempt on this.

The event is a Waacking (a dance) competition in Singapore. Competition organizer was kind enough to invite me as a photographer.

I used a slow shutter speed to capture the movement and did a close crop to isolate the dancer's face. Then converted the photos to monochrome to draw the attention to the emotions and movement.

The most challenging part of this is, capturing the movement and get an eye-pleasing image. To do that some part of the image (ideally the face/eyes) need to be sharp while other parts are blurred.

Shooting a game from pitch side. This time, I felt like an amature. I didn't bring a portable stool, nor mono-pod and my lens is not long enough (but with my 70-200mm I was still able to cover a half of the court). And I was among the few who brought only one camera. This time it was Athletics in Pesta Sukan 2023. I signed up for 5-10pm shift. Hoping to avoid the heat. Unfortunately the events ended at 5:30pm. So didn't get a much chance to shoot. Michelle Sng, She holds the Singapore National record for Female High Jump.

item.title: Ella Odyssey Trip Day 1
item.description:
After months of planing we managed to go on a trip on Ella Odyssey Train. These photos are taken on day 1 of the trip.

Train going into a tunnel. 

ISO500 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 89mm

Train reaching a railway station. 

ISO4000 | f/20.0 | 1/1000sec | 70mm

Layers of mountains seen from train window. 

ISO100 | f/6.3 | 1/1000sec | 86mm

Train leaving a railway station. Stations usually have multiple tracks. After passing the station those tracks converges to a single line. 

ISO100 | f/3.5 | 1/1000sec | 70mm

St. Clair's Falls seen from train. This is one of the widest waterfalls in Sri Lanka and is commonly known as the "Little Niagara of Sri Lanka". 

ISO100 | f/4.0 | 1/1000sec | 200mm

Another beautiful vista. 

ISO100 | f/4.5 | 1/1000sec | 158mm

Name board of Great Western railway Station. 

ISO100 | f/4.5 | 1/1000sec | 70mm

Ella-Odyssey train stops at Nine-Arch bridge. We got off from the train there. This shot is taken when the train started it's journey again. 

ISO100 | f/14.0 | 1/15sec | 29mm

Top of the Little Adam's Peak. This is in Ella. We got caught in a rain while climbing. Thankfully I managed to keep the camera dry. 

ISO250 | f/3.2 | 1/200sec | 62mm

Another shot from top of the Little Adam's Peak. 

ISO250 | f/3.2 | 1/200sec | 70mm

Ella-Wellawaya road seen from top of the Little Adam's peak. 

ISO800 | f/3.2 | 1/200sec | 70mm

We waited at the Little Adam's peak until the sunset. This is a shot of stupa with the sunset in the background. 

ISO100 | f/4.0 | 1/200sec | 200mm

item.title: Ridiyagama Safari and Hambanthota Bird Park
item.description:
Second day of the family trip. After the breakfast and another car fix up we visited the Ridiyagama safari. Where you can travel among free moving animals in a covered vehicle.

I liked the way this small deer is lighted up. 

ISO125 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 200mm

Fierce looking tiger resting. Guide said they are much more active in the mornings. 

ISO250 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 153mm

Close up of an elephant's eye. 

ISO640 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 135mm

Closeup of an antelope grazing on grass. 

ISO250 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 200mm

Then we traveled to Hambanthota Bird park. This is much well-kept compared to the Safari.

Two flamingos vibrating the water. 

ISO125 | f/2.8 | 1/800sec | 200mm

White peacock. 

ISO400 | f/3.2 | 1/800sec | 200mm

Blue parrot eating. 

ISO500 | f/2.8 | 1/800sec | 200mm

Red parrot, looking at the world outside. 

ISO100 | f/4.0 | 1/1000sec | 200mm

Blue parrots playing around. 

ISO640 | f/3.2 | 1/1000sec | 200mm

Sad looking peacock.

Caged love birds.

Toco Toucan.

item.title: Singapore Regatta Waterfest 2022
Leica Exhibition
Sengkang Cricket League Premier Final 2022
item.description:
Friend invited me to shoot a cricket match. Saturday early morning with a rainy yesterday. Ground was bit muddy.

And sun comes from the right side of the pitch. So early shots are from right side of the ground directly in line with the batsman. Later took some shots from behind the batsman to capture expressions of the bowlers. Then towards the end, from behind the bowlers.

The conclusion is 70-200mm lens is not the optimal and moving around the ground is not ideal. Much better scenario would be 4 200mm+ lenses on left, right, behind and front of the pitch. Then it would be possible to cover most of the shots.

This time it's a trip to Riverston. Located in Matale, Sri Lanka. 3+ hours drive from home and last 20km road is pretty bad.

item.title: Yapahuwa
item.description:
Yapahuwa was one of the ephemeral capitals of medieval Sri Lanka. The citadel of Yapahuwa was built around a huge granite rock rising abruptly almost a hundred meters above the surrounding lowlands[1].

In 1272, King Bhuvenakabahu transferred the capital from Polonnaruwa to Yapahuwa in the face of Dravidian invasions from South India, bringing the Sacred Tooth Relic with him. Following the death of King Bhuvenakabahu in 1284, the Pandyans of South India invaded Sri Lanka once again, and succeeded in capturing Sacred Tooth Relic. Following its capture, Yapahuwa was largely abandoned and inhabited by Buddhist monks and religious ascetics[1].

And I really missed a having a wide angle lens here.

[1]. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yapahuwa

item.title: C2C Bike Ride
item.description:
There is a trail in Singapore called Coast to Coast(C2C) trail. I went on it by bike. I was not using the GPS in the phone and relying on a pdf map. (I am trying to cut down the dependency on the mobile phone for some time now) By the time I was little bit farther than the mid point(Macritchie Reservoir), I have already travelled past 40km. Total distance of the trail is 36km. Which tells lot about my map reading skills. And it was around 4 pm already, So I turned back and came home.
